div.head: Gold color
div.ab: To very quickly make a matte layer of gold on canvas or other oil paintings, thick nut oil is made under the sun or on the fire as previously mentioned, since it thickens by itself in this way, even if it does not have any lead, nor any ceruse. And with it, grind massicot, mine, and other drying substances, but not vert-de-gris nor orpiment, since they make the gold fade. It will soon be dry. However, if the weather is not fair and dry, do not [...], because if the weather is musty and humid, the gold will blacken.

div.head: Lifelike portraiture
div.ab: One must carefully observe the eyes, the nose, and the beard, since these three things make the portrayal more lifelike.

It is necessary to pound your materials in a thick glass mortar, set with mastic into another mortar, this one of wood, so that it does not break, this can be useful to perfumers, and the pestle has to be of glass too.

div.head: Glass mortar and table for grinding
Vitrified saltpeter
div.ab: Melted with stones, it makes the glass very white. But one needs to quickly calcine it on a tile or hot shovel. And mix what remains of the vapor with as much white, calcined stones. It is true that, in the little oven, it does not clarify very well. But for big windows, it makes the glass very clear, white and clean.

div.head: Windows through which the sun does not pass
div.ab: Take the aforementioned calcined saltpeter and expose it to the air or to a humid place, and it will become a liquor which, if you rub both sides of the windows with it, the sun will not pass through at all, and it will create shade. One needs to put the saltpeter on some clean, flat surface, and put glowing coals on it, and keep it like that all over until the fire goes out.
div.note: left-bottom It is also used for melting and for mixing with alkali salt for cleaning hands.
